prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Circinus 321 GHz
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: setup for B7 321 GHz water maser

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We will observe with a bandwidth of 1875 GHz and 0.9 km/s. This setup will provide a total bandwidth of ~ 1700 km/s. The 22 GHz and 321 GHz maser spectra of Circinus display a velocity extent of 400 km/s (see Figure~2), which we will be able to cover comfortably with our current setup. We place two adjacent spectral windows contiguously, on the sideband of the maser, to detect even higher velocity lines if present (high velocity lines can be seen at 22 GHz).
The fine spectral resolution will be important to resolve narrow water maser lines, of 1 km/s. Should individual lines be broader, we will average over many channels to improve our signal-to-noise ratio. Finally, we will average all channels in the line-free sideband in each spectral setup to image the continuum in Circinus at sub-mm wavelengths.

We request here to resolve the water maser disk seen with VLBI and the VLTI in Circinus, on scales that are ~ 1pc (0.05'') or less. At band 7, we request a resolution of 0.045'' (C36-7) to resolve the maser distribution at the core (corresponding to ~ 0.8 pc in Circinus). Also, for a higher SNR (where the masers are stronger than 30 mJy) we will be able to spatially resolve a region in the disk that is smaller and likely also populated (astrometric accuracy : theta = beam / 2 X SNR).
We note that previous ALMA observation in band 7 did NOT resolve the disk (resolution was 0.66'' - corresponding to ~ 15pc), so that high angular resolution is key here. We note also that for maser studies higher angular resolution does not lower our sensitivity, since we will not resolve individual maser spots.

We propose to observe the Circinus galaxy to look for highly excited water maser emission at two different frequencies in Band 7 at 321 GHz and 325 GHz. Here we discuss the 321 GHz setup.
These masers are believed to be collisionally-pumped by a subset of the conditions that pump 22 GHz masers, for the parameter space investigated by Neufeld & Melnick (1991) and by Yates, Field & Gray (1997). The 321 GHz line was observed in Cycle 1 with ALMA (Hagiwara et al. 2013) and had a peak flux of 0.12 Jy, but more typically 30 mJy emission on most components. The masers spanned a total width of about 400 km/s. The width of individual lines range from ~ 1.5 km/s to ~ 10 km/s (figure 2, right, in the proposal). The peak continuum emission at 321 GHz was 50 mJy/beam.
With a 30\,mJy typical maser emission, we plan to observe maser lines with a SNR of 10 for a 1.5 km/s line width. This gives plenty of SNR for the two SPWs set on the continuum emission. This setup results in 45 minutes on-source time.

We will observe with a bandwidth of 1875 GHz and 0.9 km/s. This setup will provide a total bandwidth of ~ 1700 km/s. The 22 GHz and 325 GHz maser spectra of Circinus display a velocity extent of 400 km/s (see Figure~2), which we will be able to cover comfortably with our current setup. We place two adjacent spectral windows contiguously, on the sideband of the maser, to detect even higher velocity lines if present (high velocity lines are seen at 22 GHz).
The fine spectral resolution will be important to resolve narrow water maser lines, of 1 km/s. Should individual lines be broader, we will average over many channels to improve our signal-to-noise ratio. Finally, we will average all channels in the line-free sideband in each spectral setup to image the continuum in Circinus at sub-mm wavelengths.

We request here to resolve the water maser disk seen with VLBI and the VLTI in Circinus, on scales that are ~ 1pc (0.05''). At band 7, we request a resolution of 0.045'' (C36-7) to resolve the maser distribution at the core (corresponding to ~ 0.8 pc in Circinus). Also, for a higher SNR (where the masers are stronger than 30 mJy) we will be able to spatially resolve a region in the disk that is smaller and likely also populated (astrometric accuracy : theta = beam / 2 X SNR).
We note that previous ALMA observation in band 7 did not resolve the disk (resolution was 0.66'' - corresponding to ~ 15pc), so that high angular resolution is key here. We note also that for maser studies higher angular resolution does not lower our sensitivity, since we will not resolve individual maser spots.

We propose to observe the Circinus galaxy to look for highly excited water maser emission at two different frequencies in Band 7 at 321 GHz and 325 GHz. Here we discuss the 325 GHz setup.
These masers are believed to be collisionally-pumped by a subset of the conditions that pump 22 GHz masers, for the parameter space investigated by Neufeld & Melnick (1991) and by Yates, Field & Gray (1997). The 321 GHz line was observed in Cycle 1 with ALMA (Hagiwara et al. 2013) and had a peak flux of 0.12 Jy, but more typically 30 mJy emission on most components. The masers spanned a total width of about 400 km/s. The width of individual lines range from ~ 1.5 km/s to ~ 10 km/s (figure 2 right, in the proposal). The peak continuum emission at 321 GHz was 50 mJy/beam.
From the recent ALMA results on VY CMa (Richards et al. 2014, Figure 1, right) we saw that the 321 GHz and 325 GHz masers were comparable in strength, velocity range and line width. So we can assume similar parameters as for the 321 GHz line.
However, the 325 GHz falls in a deep absorption trough in the atmosphere (due to the water line itself), so that observing this transition is more challenging. For this reason we relax our detection constraints, and make sure we have enough sensitivity to detect the fainter masers with SNR 3 (and higher for the stronger peaks in the spectrum). Also, we average over 4 km/s, which is enough to detect the narrower lines, but leaves us the option to average more for broader components. We keep two SPWs to image the continuum emission. This setup results in 47 minutes on-source time.

We will observe with a bandwidth of 1875 GHz and 0.4 km/s, averaging over 8 channels. This setup will provide a total bandwidth of ~ 870 km/s, and a spectral resolution of ~ 2 km/s. The 22 GHz and 325 GHz maser spectra of Circinus display a velocity extent of 400 km/s (see Figure~2), which we will be able to cover comfortably with our current setup. We place two adjacent spectral windows contiguously, on the sideband of the maser, to detect even higher velocity lines if present (high velocity lines are seen at 22 GHz), or if the line is broader.
The fine spectral resolution will be important to resolve narrow water maser lines, of 2 km/s, if they are present. Since we expect broader lines in this transition, we will be able to average over many channels to improve our signal-to-noise ratio. Finally, we will average all channels in the line-free continuum sideband in each TDM spectral setup to image the continuum in Circinus.

We request here to resolve the water maser disk seen with VLBI and the VLTI in Circinus, on scales that are ~ 1pc (0.05''). At band 9, we request a resolution of 0.047'' (C36-6) to resolve the maser distribution at the core (corresponding to ~ 0.8 pc in Circinus). Also, for a higher SNR (where the masers are stronger than 60 mJy) we will be able to spatially resolve a region that is smaller than the beam (astrometric accuracy : theta = beam / 2 X SNR).
We note that previous ALMA observation in band 7 did not resolve the disk (resolution was 0.66'' - corresponding to ~ 15pc), so that high angular resolution is key here. We also expect the 658 GHz emission to be more compact.
We note also that for maser studies higher angular resolution does not lower our sensitivity, since we do not expect to resolve individual maser spots.

We propose to observe the Circinus galaxy to look for highly excited water maser emission in Band 9 at 658 GHz.
So far, only the 321 GHz line was observed in Cycle 1 with ALMA (Hagiwara et al. 2013) and it was detected with a peak flux of 0.12 Jy, but more typically 30 mJy emission on most components. The masers spanned a total width of about 400 km/s. The width of individual lines range from ~ 1.5 km/s to ~ 10 km/s (figure 2, right, in the proposal). The peak continuum emission at 321 GHz was 40 mJy/beam.
There are no direct detections of the 658 GHz transition. However, from the recent ALMA results on VY CMa (Richards et al. 2014, Figure 1, right) we saw that the 321 GHz and 325 GHz masers were comparable in flux density, whereas the 658 GHz line was actually the strongest one, after the 22 GHz line, and about twice as strong as the 321 GHz emission. The 658 GHz line is also wider and has less fine components. If similar condistions exist, we can assume a typical line flux density of 60 mJy, with a broader line width of say, 20 km/s.
For a SNR of 10 on a 20 km/s line, we get an on-source time of 39 minutes.
We keep two TDM SPWs set on the continuum emission, in order to image the continuum emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water megamasers provide the best means of probing the physical conditions and accurate geometries within less than 1 pc of active galactic nuclei (AGN). Sub-millimeter water masers will allow us to investigate with unprecended detail the accretion disk and map so far uncharted regions. This is only now possible thanks to the superior sensitivity and resolution that ALMA provides. We propose here a sensitive search for sub-millimeter water maser lines at 321, 325 and 658 GHz towards the Circinus galaxy, which is the nearest AGN hosting a powerful pc-scale maser disk. The detection of these lines will give us an entirely new insight into the kinematics and physical state of the accreting material in Circinus. An analysis of the strength and distribution will allow us to: i) map the gas temperature and density at very high angular resolution, ii) improve our geometric disk models, iii) test unification schemes and iv) constrain radiative transfer models. These observations will also provide a crucial stepping stone for VLBI observations which include the the ALMA Phased Array (APP), already starting in Cycle 4 observations.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00189.S : The molecular torus in the active galactic nucleus in the Circinus galaxy (PI: Tristram).
